awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Development of high-performance terahertz intersubband lasers
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research is to develop semiconductor laser sources of terahertz radiationbased on GaAs/AlGaAs quantum-cascade superlattices. The first goal is to realize lasers that can operate above room-temperature, which do not exist presently. The approach is to utilize new design methodologies for temperature-robust electron transport in quantum-cascade structures. The second goal is to demonstrate the first hole-based quantum-cascade laser and investigate hole-hole intersubband transport in valence band of semiconductors. Hole-based intersubband lasers and detectors will allow surface-normal coupling of radiation with enhanced quantum efficiencies.

The intellectual merit is in new schemes of carrier transport for quantum-cascade semiconductor superlattices. For electron-based designs, injectorless and scattering-assisted injection schemes will be utilized that are expected to be more temperature robust than the presently used resonant-tunneling injection methods. For hole-based designs, radiative transitions between light and heavy holes would be explored that enable light emission in the surface-normal direction.

Room-temperature semiconductor terahertz lasers will fill a critical gap for the underdeveloped terahertz spectrum, in applications related to health, medicine and security. Outcomes of this research will enable development of low-cost and compact instruments for terahertz sensing and spectroscopy of chemical and biological species, such as drugs, explosives, vaccines, proteins, pharmaceutical compounds, and terahertz imaging for disease diagnosis as well as remote screening for defense and security. The project will lead to interdisciplinary educational and research opportunities at the undergraduate level. At the community level, concepts in photonics and quantum-mechanics would be introduced in an annual optics workshop for elementary/ middle-school students.

por.por_cntn:
Technical outcomes
The primary goal of this project was to develop high-performance terahertz (THz) semiconductor quantum cascade lasers (QCLs) in the GaAs/AlGaAs material system to bring them closer to commercialization similar to the mid-infrared QCLs that have been commercially available for more than a decade. Aspects related to improvement of temperature performance, threshold characteristics, frequency tunability, and power output and spectral characteristics of existing THz QCLs were all addressed during the course of the project. Following are the primary technical outcomes of the project:

(a) A novel phase-locking scheme was developed for metallic microcavities that are used as waveguides for THz QCLs. Record-highest output power for single-mode THz semiconductor lasers was demonstrated in pulsed mode of operation, with multi-Watt peak-power emission when the QCLs were operated in a compact electrically operated Stirling cryocooler. Record highest radiative efficiency was also experimentally demonstrated for any such QCL to-date.

(b) Electrical tuning of single-mode THz lasers is difficult to achieve because of the tight mode confinement in the metallic cavities of such QCLs that use plasmonic resonant-optical modes. Through this project, a new type of semiconductor superlattice design was developed that could achieve electrically tunable emission from single-mode THz QCLs with directional beams, by altering the refractive-index of the gain medium of the laser through voltage-induced changes in the electron transport in such superlattices.

(c) A custom technique for wavelength beam combining of monolithic THz QCL arrays emitting at a range of wavelengths on a single semiconductor chip was also demonstrated, with a goal toward targeting applications in THz spectroscopy at standoff distances. Robust single-mode and single-lobed radiative emission was achieved at lithographically designed frequencies in a certain frequency range for multiple QCLs on a single semiconductor chip. Secondly, custom THz lenses and optical blazed gratings for THz frequencies were developed for maximum focusing and grating efficiencies (since such lenses and gratings are not commercially available for THz frequencies).

(d) Scattering due to interface-roughness (IR) and longitudinal-optical (LO) phonons are primary transport mechanisms in THz QCLs. By choosing GaAs/AlGaAs heterostructures with short-barriers, the effect of IR scattering is mitigated, leading to low operating current-densities. As a result of this project, a series of THz QCLs with some of the lowest threshold and peak current-densities were experimentally demonstrated.

Broader outcomes
Development of high-power THz lasers has the potential to enable a host of commercial applications and economic activity in THz spectroscopy, sensing, and imaging. Laser based THz instruments and measurement techniques could lead to new insights in fields as diverse as cell-biology for study of biomolecular structure and dynamics, non-destructive evaluation and detection of drugs, pharmaceutical products, explosives, non-invasive imaging of biological samples, and remote-sensing of Earth's atmosphere and outer space. THz QCLs with such properties would fill the void that still remains to target applications in the underdeveloped THz region of the electromagnetic spectrum. 

Over the course of this project, important advances were made toward development of THz QCLs that will allow proof-of-concept demonstration of a compact and low-cost THz spectroscopy system. THz QCLs that could simultaneously attain high power output in a narrow beam with good beam quality, and an ability to electrically tune the frequency of the QCL while QCL is operated at a relatively high operating temperature (above 60K) that will eliminate the use of cryogens such as liquid Helium and liquid Nitrogen, could then be used to make multi-laser DFB arrays on monolithic semiconductor chips for rapid broadband THz spectroscopy of analytes (chemical and biomolecular samples) with a low-cost and compact cryogen-free system. Such a THz spectroscopy instrument for THz sensing of liquids and/or gases is not presently available, and hence this development will provide a transformational impact in the field of THz science and technology.

Elements of research were incorporated in both undergraduate and graduate-level courses in photonics and semiconductor-physics at Lehigh University. THz science and technology and quantum cascade lasers were introduced in both undergraduate as well as graduate courses. Specifically, the concept of plasmonic cavities was introduced in an undergraduate course on electromagnetics and a graduate course in photonics. Second, the concept of one-dimensional semiconductor superlattices to create bandstructures with desired characteristics using semiconductor heterostructures was introduced in a graduate course on semiconductor physics.

This project has provided opportunities to four doctoral students at Lehigh University (partially, at different stages) to get advanced training in the fields of semiconductor optoelectronics, THz science and technology, and semiconductor physics. Additionally, the project also provided a platform to the students to understand various methods related to finite-element modeling of physics problems, and quantum-transport calculations for semiconductor superlattices and heterostructures. Students also receive valuable experience in the science of nanofabrication, cryogenic test and measurement, and measurements related to long- wavelength (far-infrared/THz) radiation. This knowledge also prepares students for topics related to imaging and spectroscopy.
